slots.stats:
Returns a Map with servers' statistics. Keys are server addresses,
values are maps with actual stats.
slots.incr([offset]):
Asks memcached to increment data for some item in place. The data for the item is
treated as decimal representation of a 64-bit unsigned integer. If the
current data value does not conform to such a representation, the
commands behave as if the value were 0.
Default offset is 1.
Returns the new value.
slots.replace(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key,
but only if the server *does* already hold data for this key.
Returns true on success, false if there is already data for this key.
Otherwise raises an exception.
slots.add(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key,
but only if the server *doesn't* already hold data for this key.
Returns true on success, false in case of a collision.
Otherwise raises an exception.
slots.removeAt(key): Asks memcached to remove value with a given key. Returns self.
slots.at(key, optionalDefaultValue):
Asks memcached to retrieve data corresponding to the key.
	Returns nil if the data is not there (or if the data *is* nil).
slots.atIfAbsentPut(key, value[, expiration]):
If a value is present at the specified key, its value is returned.
	Otherwise, inserts the new value and returns it.
slots.atPut(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key.
	Same as Memcached set, but returns self.
slots.getMulti(keys):
Asks memcached to retrieve data corresponding to the list of keys.
Returns a Map with the results.
If some of the keys appearing in a retrieval request are not sent back
by the server in the item list this means that the server does not
hold items with such keys
slots.flushAll([expiration]):
Asks memcached to invalidate all existing items immediately (by default)
or after the expiration specified.
Always returns true.
slots.addServer(address):
Adds a memcached server. address is a "host:port" string, e.g., "127.0.0.1:11211"
Returns self.
slots.append(key, value):
Asks memcached to add this value to an existing key after existing value.
Returns true on success, otherwise raises an exception.
value should be a Sequence.
Supported by memcached 1.2.4+
slots.with(servers):
Returns a new instance of Memcached.
	Accepts a Sequence or a List of server addresses.
slots.set(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key.
Returns true on success, otherwise raises an exception.
slots.prepend(key, value):
Asks memcached to add this value to an existing key before existing value.
Returns true on success, otherwise raises an exception.
value should be a Sequence.
Supported by memcached 1.2.4+
slots.delete(key[, time]):
Asks memcached to delete an item with the given key.
time is the amount of time in seconds (or Unix time until which)
the client wishes the server to refuse "add" and "replace" commands
with this key.
Returns true on success, false if there is no item with the given key.
Otherwise raises an exception.
slots.get(key):
Asks memcached to retrieve data corresponding to the key.
Raises "NOT FOUND" if the data is not there.
slots.decr([offset]):
Asks memcached to decrement data for some item in place. The data for the item is
treated as decimal representation of a 64-bit unsigned integer. If the
current data value does not conform to such a representation, the
commands behave as if the value were 0.
Default offset is 1.
Returns the new value.

Memcached.description: memcached is a high-performance, distributed memory object caching system, generic in nature, but intended for use in speeding up dynamic web applications by alleviating database load. Memcached is an Io client library for memcached, based on C libmemcached.

Obsidian.description: A double key/value database with cursors on first key. Basis for PDB.

PMap.description:
PMap stores persistent data in a Map-like fashion and lazily loads
available slots from the PDB backing store. Values stored or loaded are cached
into local object slots.

slots.atPut(slotName, value): Records value in the slot named slotName.
slots.at(slotName):
Tries to obtain a value for slot slotName from a local slot of that name, or tries to load it from the PDB if the local slot does not exist. When all else fails, returns nil.

If slotName begins with an underscore ("_"), returns the id of the slot from PDB instead of the value.
slots.persistSlots: Cleans up dirty slots by committing them to PDB.
slots.persist: Commits the PMap's slots to PDB.
slots.shouldPersistByDefault:
PDB boolean flag indicating whether this object should be considered for persistence
when persistence has not been specifically requested by calling ppid() or PDB addObjectToPersist.
Always true by default for PMap.
slots.slotCount: Returns the number of slots committed to PDB.
slots.objectsForKeys:
Returns a list of values for each key in the list given. Keys beginning with an
underscore ("_") are returned verbatim.
slots.init: Initialize a new PMap and automatically add it as a persistent object to PDB.
slots.createIfAbsent: Creates a slot with a new PMap clone if not already present.

ObsidianServer.description:
A network interface for Obsidian.

Starting a Server

oServer := ObsidianServer clone
oServer localObject setName("foo") open
oServer start

Example Client Code

client := MDOConnection clone setHost("127.0.0.1") setPort(8000) connect
client onAtPut("1", "aKey", "aSlot")
client onAtPut("1", "cKey", "cSlot")
client onAtPut("1", "bKey", "bSlot")
client first("1", 5) println
a := client onAt("1", "aKey")
writeln("a = ", a)
b := client onAt("1", "bKey")
writeln("b = ", b)
client close
The messages accepted by the Obsidian server include: 
onAtPut(id, key, value)
onAt(id, key)
onRemoveAt(id, key)
onFirst(id, count)
onLast(id, count)
onAfter(id, key, count)
onBefore(id, key, count)

slots.objectAtPpid: Return the object associated in the database with a ppid.
slots.collectGarbage: Remove from PDB all objects not accessible via the root object.
slots.show: Print to standard output a listing of all objects and IDs stored in PDB.
slots.newId: Generate a new PDB id number for use as a persistent object's ppid.
slots.sync:
Immediately persist data for all objects marked dirty by Collector whose 
shouldPersistByDefault is true, or that have specifically requested to be
persisted since the last sync via addObjectToPersist.
slots.reopen: Sync, close and reopen the PDB store.
slots.root: Return the root PMap object used to store and retrieve persistent objects and their slots.
slots.addObjectToPersist: Register an object to be persisted in the next PDB sync.

PDB.description:
An arbitrary graph database with support for on-disk garbage collection. Example use:

Setup

PDB open
PDB root atPut("users", PMap clone)
PDB sync
PDB close
PMap is a Map/Dictionary whose keys are lazily loaded from the database. PDB root is the root PMap in the database and the root object used for PDB's garbage collector. PDB sync needs to be called to write any changes to the database.

Defining a Persistent Object

User := Object clone pSlots(name, email)
The pSlots(), declares which slots on the object should be persisted. The List, Date, Sequence and Number primitives already know how to persist themselves.

Inserting a Persistent Object

PDB open 
user := User clone setName("steve") setEmail("steve@foo.com")
PDB root users atPut("steve", user)
PDB sync
PDB close

Accessing a Persistent Object

user := PDB root users at("steve")
writeln("user name = ", user name, " email = ", user email)

Updating a Persistent Object

user setEmail("steve@newDomain.com")
PDB sync
PDB sync will scan all persistent objects in the vm and save any with changes to their persistent slots. If the object was already in the database, only its updated slots will be written.

Removing an entry in a PMap

PDB root users removeAt("steve")

Removing a persistent object

This is never done explicitly, instead calling: 
PDB collectGarbage
Will remove all objects unreachable by the reference graph from the root PMap.

Notes: Currently, PDB is a singleton.

SQLite3.description:
SQLite provides a embedded simple and fast (2x faster than PostgreSQL or MySQL) SQL database. See http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/ for details. It's SQL command set is described at http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/lang.html. SQLite was written by Dr. Richard Hipp who offers consulting services for custom modifications and support of SQLite. Example: 

	
db := SQLite clone
db setPath("myDatabase.sqlite")
db open
db exec("CREATE TABLE Dbm (key, value)")
db exec("CREATE INDEX DbmIndex ON Dbm (key)")
db exec("INSERT INTO Dbm ('key', 'value') VALUES ('a', '123')")
db exec("INSERT INTO Dbm ('key', 'value') VALUES ('a', 'efg')")
rows := db exec("SELECT key, value FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
db exec("DELETE FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
rows := db exec("SELECT key, value FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
db close

my close

TagDB.description:
Binding for tagdb - a tagging database usefull for flickr-like tag searches.

Example use: 

tdb := TagDB clone

tdb setPath("test")
tdb open

writeln("size = ", tdb size)
tdb atKeyPutTags("f430 for sale", list("red", "ferrari"))
tdb atKeyPutTags("lotus esprit", list("lotus", "esprit"))
writeln("size = ", tdb size)
keys := tdb keysForTags(list("lotus"))
writeln("keys = ", tdb symbolForId(keys at(0)))
tdb close
tdb delete

DBIRecord.description:
A DBI Record. When utilizing `foreach' or `populate' methods of a DBIResult object, you can pass an optional Object cloned from DBIRecord. This object will be populated with the row contents making it possible to write objects that represent your SQL results. A simple example would be: 
Person := DBIRecord clone do (fullName := method(firstName.." "..lastName))
q := conn query("SELECT id, firstName, lastName FROM people")
q foreach(Person, p, writeln("Name = ", p fullName))
As you can see, fullName was not in the SQL query, however, a dynamic method in your Person class. DBIRecord in and of itself provides no real functionality. It simply acts as an Object and stores the values from the SQL query into a Map. You can access the field information: 
o := r populate(Person)
o firstName            // would retrieve the firstName value of the SQL query
o setFirstName("John") // would update the object's firstName value to be John
Do not confuse the above example as updating the actual database. The call to setFirstName only updates the objects representation of firstName.

slots.with(aMap): Returns a new DBIRecord instance for the given value map.
slots.forward: Private method that implements getting and setting values.

slots.next: Move the cursor to the next record.
slots.position: Return the current row's position (or index).
slots.seek(row_number): Move the cursor to the nth record.
slots.last: Move the cursor to the last record.
slots.done: Close and free the result. This must be called on each result. Failure to do so will cause memory leaks and open queries with the database server.
slots.foreach([Object], value, message):
Loops over the records in the result starting at either the first result (if the cursor has never been moved) or its current location if moved. i.e. 
r := conn query("SELECT * FROM people")
r foreach(r, r at(1))
The above would start at the first row, however, you can move around in the result set and then foreach would pickup where you left off, for instance, say you wanted to skip the first three rows: 
r := conn query("SELECT * FROM people")
r seek(4)
r foreach(r, r at (1))
The above would start at the record #4, not at the beginning. The optional Object parameter would cause a decendent of DBIRecord to be populate instead of the index being set. This allows for advanced functionality. Please see `DBIRecord' for further information and an example.
slots.previous: Move the cursor to the previous record.

Returns the contents of the given field.

Font.description:
The Font object can be used to load and render TypeTrype fonts. Example use; 
	
// within a GLUT display callback...

timesFont = Font clone open(\"times.ttf\")
if (timesFont error, write(\"Error loading font: \", timesFont error, \"\n\"); return)
timesFont setPointSize(16)
glColor(0,0,0,1)
timesFont draw(\"This is a test.\")
Rendering fonts using OpenGL textures

Smaller fonts (those having a point size around 30 or smaller, depending on the font) will automatically be cached in and rendered from a texture. This technique is very fast and should support rendering speeds as fast (or faster than) those of typical desktop font rendering systems. Larger font sizes(due to texture memory constraints) will be rendered to a pixelmap when displayed. Thanks to Mike Austin for implementing the font texturing system.

image = Image clone open("curly.png")

Currently supported formats include PNG(which supports alpha), JPG and TIFF.

slots.pattern: Returns the pattern string that the receiver was created from.
slots.isMultiline: Returns true if the receiver is in multiline mode, false if not.
slots.dotAll:
Returns a clone of the receiver with the dotall option turned on, or self if the receiver itself has the option turned on.

In dotall mode, "." matches any character, including newline. By default it matches any character except newline.

	
	Io> "A\nB" matchesOfRegex(".+") next string
	==> A

	Io> "A\nB" matchesOfRegex(".+" asRegex dotAll) next string
	==> A\nB
slots.nameTable:
Returns a list with the name of each capture.
	The first element will always be nil, because it corresponds to the whole match.
	The second element will contain the name of the first capture, or nil if the first
	capture has no name.
	And so on.
slots.isDotAll: Returns true if the receiver is in dotall mode, false if not.
slots.asString: Returns a string containing a textual representation of the receiver.
slots.names:
Returns a list of the name of each named capture.
	If there are no named captures, the list will be empty.
slots.namedCaptures: Returns a Map that contains the index of each named group.
slots.isExtended: Returns true if the receiver is in extended mode, false if not.
slots.with(pattern): Returns a new Regex created from the given pattern string.
slots.caseless:
Returns a case insensitive clone of the receiver, or self if the receiver itself is case insensitive: 
	
	Io> "WORD" matchesRegex("[a-z]+")
	==> false

	Io> "WORD" matchesRegex("[a-z]+" asRegex caseless)
	==> true
slots.multiline:
Returns a clone of the receiver with the multiline option turned on, or self if the receiver itself has the option turned on.

In multiline mode, "^" matches at the beginning of the string and at the beginning of each line; and "$" matches at the end of the string, and at the end of each line. By default "^" only matches at the beginning of the string, and "$" only matches at the end of the string.

	
	Io> "A\nB\nC" allMatchesForRegex("^.")
	==> list("A")

	Io> "A\nB\nC" allMatchesForRegex("^." asRegex multiline)
	==> list("A", "B", "C")
slots.extended:
Returns a clone of the receiver with the extended option turned on, or self if the receiver itself has the option turned on.

In extended mode, a Regex ignores any whitespace character in the pattern except when escaped or inside a character class. This allows you to write clearer patterns that may be broken up into several lines.

Additionally, you can put comments in the pattern. A comment starts with a "#" character and continues to the end of the line, unless the "#" is escaped or is inside a character class.
slots.version: Returns a string with PCRE version information.
slots.captureCount: Returns the number of captures defined by the pattern.
slots.isCaseless: Returns true if the receiver is case insensitive, false if not.
slots.matchesIn(aString):
Returns a RegexMatches object that enumerates the matches of the receiver
	in the given string.

Regex.description:
The Regex addon adds support for Perl regular expressions using the PCRE library by Philip Hazel.

Example 1

	
Io> re := "is.*a" asRegex
Io> "This is a test. This is also a test." \
    allMatchesOfRegex(" is[^.]*a") replaceAllWith(" is not a")
==> "This is not a test. This is not a test.

Example 2

	
Io> "11aabb" allMatchesOfRegex("aa*")
==> list("a", "a")

Io> re := "(wom)(bat)" asRegex
Io> "wombats are cuddly" matchesOfRegex(re) replaceAllWith("$2$1!")
==> batwom!s are cuddly

slots.at(indexOrName): Returns the capture with the given index or name. at(0) is the entire match.
slots.startOf(indexOrName): Returns the index into the subject at which the capture with the given index or name starts.
slots.foreach([index], capture, message): Loops through the captures, assigns each capture to capture, and evaluates message. Returns a list with the result of each evaluation.
slots.map([index], capture, message): Like foreach, but the result of each evaluation of message is returned in a list.
slots.asString: Returns a string containing a textual representation of the receiver.
slots.prefix:
Returns a slice of the subject string that contains all text before this match. Equivalent to: 
	match subject slice(0, match start)
slots.ranges: Returns a list containing the range of each capture.
slots.postfix:
Returns a slice of the subject string that contains all text after this match. Equivalent to: 
	match subject slice(match end)
slots.names:
Returns a list of the name of each named capture.
	If there are no named captures, the list will be empty.
slots.end: Returns the index into the subject at which the match ends.
slots.rangeOf(indexOrName): Returns the range of the capture with the given index or name.
slots.start: Returns the index into the subject at which the match starts.
slots.select([index], capture, message): Like foreach, but the values for which the result of evaluating message are non-nil are returned in a list.
slots.captures: Returns a list of captured strings. The first element is the whole match.
slots.slice(startIndex, [endIndex]): Returns a new list containing the subset of the receiver from the startIndex to the endIndex. The endIndex argument is optional. If not given, it is assumed to be the end of the capture list.
slots.range: Returns the range of the match in the subject.
slots.endOf(indexOrName): Returns the index into the subject at which the capture with the given index or name ends.
slots.expandTo(templateString): Returns templateString with capture placeholders replaced with what they represent. $0 is replaced with the whole match, $1 is replaced with the first sub capture, etc. ${name} is replaced with the capture of that name.
slots.sizeInChars: Returns the length of the match, in characters.
slots.nameOf(index): Returns the name of the capture with the given index.
slots.indexOf(name): Returns the index of the capture with the given name.
slots.regex: Returns the Regex that was used to find this match.
slots.subject: Returns the string that this match was found in.

RegexMatch.description:
Contains the result of a regular expression match operation. It acts as a read-only list of captured strings. The first item is the entire matched string. Each item after that is a captured sub pattern (anything inbetween parenthesis in the pattern). 
Io> match := "37signals" findRegex("([0-9]+)([a-z]+)(!!)?")
==> RegexMatch: "37signals" 

# Item 0 is the entire matched string:
Io> match at(0)
==> 37signals

# Item 1 is the first capture ("[0-9]+"):
Io> match at(1)
==> 37

# Item 2 is the second capture ("[a-z]+"):
Io> match at(2)
==> signals

# The third sub pattern wasn't part of the match, so item 3 is nil:
Io> match at(3)
==> nil

# You can access captures by name, if you name them:
Io> match := "37signals" findRegex("(?[0-9]+)(?[a-z]+)(!!)?")
==> RegexMatch: "37signals"
Io> match at("number")
==> 37
Io> match at("word")
==> signals

slots.last: Returns the last match in the string.
slots.string: Returns the string that the receiver finds matches in.
slots.allowsEmptyMatches: Returns true if the receiver allows empty matches, false if not.
slots.setString(aString): Sets the string to find matches in. Returns self.
slots.foreachInterval(value, matchMessage, non: Like foreach, but takes an extra message that will be evaluated for the non-matching text before each match, and the non-matching text after the last match.
slots.replace(name, message): Replaces each match in the string with the result of message and returns the resulting string.
slots.map(value, message): Like foreach, but the result of each evaluation of message is returned in a list.
slots.setPosition(aRegexOrString): Sets the search position to the given index in the string. Returns self.
slots.splitString:
Splits the string being matched against into pieces using the regex as the delimiter
	and returns the piece as a list of strings.
slots.all: Returns a list containing all matches in the string.
slots.next: Returns the next match, or nil if there is none.
slots.setEndPosition(anIndex):
Sets the index in the string where the receiver should stop searching. It will be as if the string ends at that index. If index is nil, the end position will be set to the end of string. Returns self. 
	Io> "funkadelic" matchesOfRegex("\\w+") setEndPosition(4) next string
	==> funk

	Io> "funkadelic" matchesOfRegex("\\w+") setEndPosition(nil) next string
	==> funkadelic
slots.endPosition: Returns the index in the string where the receiver stops searching.
slots.foreach(value, message): Loops through the matches, assigns each match to value, and evaluates message. Returns the result of the last evaluation.
slots.anchored: Like next, but will only match at the current search position.
slots.regex: Returns the Regex that the receiver uses for finding matching.
slots.position: Returns the search position as an index in the string.
slots.setRegex(aRegexOrString): Sets the regex to find matches in. Returns self.
slots.disallowEmptyMatches: Tells the receiver not to allow zero length matches. Returns self.
slots.allowEmptyMatches:
Tells the receiver to allow zero length matches. Empty matches are allowed by default.
	Returns self.

slots.setPattern(aString): Sets the pattern string. Returns self.
slots.caseFoldOn: Ignore case distinctions in both the pattern and the string.
slots.string: The string to do matching on.
slots.hasMatch: Returns true if a match is found, false otherwise.
slots.pathNameOn:
If set, a slash (/) character in string will be explicitly matched 
	by a slash in pattern; it will not be matched by either the asterisk (*) 
	or question-mark (?) special characters, nor by a bracket ([]) expression. 
	If not set, the slash character is treated as an ordinary character.
slots.setString(aString): Sets the string to do matching on.
slots.leadingDirOn: Ignore rest after successful pattern matching.
slots.periodOn:
If set, a leading period in string will match a period in pattern; where the location of ``leading'' is indicated by the value of FNM_PATHNAME:
  • If FNM_PATHNAME is set, a period is ``leading'' if it is the first character in string or if it immediately follows a slash.
  • If FNM_PATHNAME is not set, a period is ``leading'' only if it is the first character of string.

If not set, no special restrictions are placed on matching a period.
slots.matchFor(aString): Returns self if aString matches the pattern, otherwise returns nil.
slots.noEscapeOn:
If not set, a backslash character (\) in pattern followed by any other 
	character will match that second character in string. 
	In particular, "\\" will match a backslash in string. 
	If set, a backslash character will be treated as an ordinary character.

Clutter.description:
Clutter is a GObject based library for creating fast, visually rich, graphical user interfaces.

Clutter works by manipulating a scene-graph of 2D surfaces, or 'actors', inside a 3D space.

ClutterActor is the base class for such surfaces. All ClutterActors can be positioned, scaled and rotated in 3D space. In addition, other properties can be set, such as 2D clipping, children and opacity. Tranforms applied to a parent actor also apply to any children. Actors are also able to receive events.

Subclasses of ClutterActor include ClutterStage, ClutterTexture, ClutterLabel, ClutterRectangle, ClutterEntry and ClutterGroup. ClutterActors are added to a parent, transformed and then made visible.

ClutterStage is the top level ClutterActor - it's the representation of a window, or framebuffer. It is created automatically when Clutter is initialised. ClutterStage is a ClutterGroup, a class implementing the ClutterCointainer interface.

ClutterTimelines provide the basis for Clutter's animation utilities. Multiple timelines can be synchronised using ClutterScore, and ClutterBehaviour and ClutterEffect allow for the creation of animation effects such as transitions.

Clutter further contains a number of utilities, including; ClutterScript - for loading 'UI definition' files formatted in JSON, ClutterShader - a class for applying GPU shaders to actors, ClutterModel - a utility class for MVC list type implementations, and fixed point math utilities.

For detailed docs, see clutter-project.

MDOServer.description:
A Minimal Distributed Objects server. Example; 
DateServer := Object clone do(
	acceptedMessageNames := list("currentDate")
	currentDate := method(Date clone asNumber)
)

mdoServer := MDOServer clone 
mdoServer setHost("127.0.0.1")  setPort(8123) 
mdoServer setLocalObject(DateServer clone)
mdoServer start

MDOConnection.description:
A Minimal Distributed Objects connection. Example; 
dateServerCon := MDOConnection clone setHost("127.0.0.1") setPort(8123) connect
writeln("date from date server: ", Date fromNumber(dateServerCon currentDate))
dateServerCon close
See the docs for MDOServer for the DateServer code.

A MDOConnection will pause calling coroutines until the response is received. Mutliple requests can be sent before a single request returns if they are sent from separate coroutines.

DOServer.description:
An experimental distributed objects server. Example; 
Test := Object clone
Test test := method(v, 
	write("got test '", v, "'\n")
	return List clone append(1)
)

doServer := DOServer clone
doServer setRootObject(Test clone)
doServer setPort(8456)
doServer start

slots.setRootObject(anObject): Sets the root object which incoming messages will be sent to.

DOConnection.description:
The DOConnection object is useful for communicating with remote servers in a way that makes it look just like the sending of local messages. Proxies are automatically created on either side for passed objects, with the exception of strings and numbers, which are passed by value. Example: 
con := DOConnection clone setHost("127.0.0.1") setPort(8456) connect
result := con serverObject test(1)
writeln(result)
r := result at(0)
writeln(r)
r := result at(1)
writeln(r)
Implementation Notes:

The format of the Distributed Objects message is a list of NullCharacter terminated strings in one of these two formats:

Send message format: 

s NullCharacter targetId NullCharacter messageName NullCharacter argCount NullCharacter argType NullCharacter argValue NullCharacter (next arg type and value, etc)
Reply message format: 
r NullCharacter argType NullCharacter argvalue NullCharacter
If the argument is not a String, Number or nil then: If it is local to the sender, the type is RemoteObject. If it is a proxy to a remote object, the type is LocalObject. This isn't optimized yet.

slots.setPort(portNumber): Sets the port number to connect to. Returns self.
slots.serverObject: A handle to the remote DOServer's root object. Returns result from server or an Error, if one occurs.
slots.connect: Connect to the remote DOServer. Returns self or an Error, if one occurs.
slots.close: Close the connection, if it is open. Returns self.
slots.setHost(ipString): Sets the host ip to connect to. Returns self or an Error, if one occurs.

CGI.description:
CGI supports accessing CGI parameters passed in environment variables or standard input by a web servers like Apache. Example use: 
#!./ioServer

cgi = CGI clone

redirect = cgi getParameters at("redirurl")
if (redirect and redirect != "",
	redirect clipAfterStartOfSeq("\r")
	redirect clipAfterStartOfSeq("\n")
	cgi redirect(redirect)
	System exit(0)
 )

cgi header("Content-type", "text/html")

cgi write("<html><head><title>test</title><body>")
cgi write("GET Parameters:")
cgi getParameters foreach(k, v,
	cgi write(k .. " = " .. v .. ","))
)

cgi write("POST Parameters:")
cgi postParameters foreach(k, v,
	cgi write(k .. " = " .. v .. ","))
)

cgi write("COOKIES:")
cgi cookies foreach(k, v,
	cgi write(k .. " = " .. v .. ",")
)

slots.reserve(timeout): Returns and reserves a job (waits until one becomes available if necessary)
slots.bury(id, pri): Puts a job into the "buried" state
slots.delete(id): Removes a job with a given id from the server, entirely
slots.release(id): Puts a reserved job back into the ready queue
slots.put(body, pri, delay, ttr):
Inserts a job into the queue.
pri - priority, an integer < 2**32. Jobs with smaller priority values will be scheduled before jobs with larger priorities. The most urgent priority is 0; the least urgent priority is 4294967295.
delay - an integer number of seconds to wait before putting the job in the ready queue. The job will be in the "delayed" state during this time.
ttr - time to run, an integer number of seconds to allow a worker to run this job.
slots.touch(id): Allows a worker to request more time to work on a job.
slots.connect(address): Connects to a beanstalk server. address is a "host:port" string, e.g., "127.0.0.1:11300"

Beanstalk.credits: Aleksey Yeschenko, 2009. Default arguments and some other things taken from beanstalk-client-ruby by Keith Rarick.
Beanstalk.description:
beanstalkd is a fast, distributed, in-memory workqueue service. See http://xph.us/software/beanstalkd/
An example from http://xph.us/software/beanstalkd/:
First, have one process put a job into the queue: 
producer := Beanstalk clone connect("127.0.0.1:11300")
producer put("hello")
Then start another process to take jobs out of the queue and run them: 
worker := Beanstalk clone connect("127.0.0.1:11300")
loop(
	job := worker reserve
	job body println # prints "hello"
	job delete
)
See Beanstalk.io code and protocol description (http://github.com/kr/beanstalkd/tree/master/doc/protocol.txt) for details. Both are short and easy to read.
Stat commands depend on YAML.

Loudmouth.description:
Loudmouth is an async XMPP library written in C. Example usage: 
acc := Loudmouth with("user@server.com", "super password") do(
  handleConnect = method(
    "Connected!" println)

  handleMessage = method(msg
    "#{msg from} > #{msg plainBody}" println
    body :=  msg plainBody

    if(body indexOf("#") == 0,
      body = doString(body) asString)

    # This way you can manipulate
    # XML nodes with SGML addon
    XmppChatMessage create\
      setPlainBody(body)\
      setTo(msg from)\
      sendVia(self)

    # or simply send the message (must be a Sequence)
    # (this is obviously faster)
    #self send(msg from, body))
)

acc connect
# Any Io code after this line won't be executed
# (unless called as Loudmouth callback or run in separate thread)
Loudmouth startMainLoop

EventManager.description:

	Usefull for getting notifications for descriptor (a socket or file) events.
	Events include read (the descriptor has unread data or timeout) and write (the descriptor wrote some data or timeout).
	Also, timer and signal events are supported.

Server.description:
The Server object provides a simple interface for running a server. You just need to set the port and define a handleSocket method. Here's an example of an echo server: 
Echo := Object clone
Echo handleSocketFromServer := method(aSocket, aServer,
  write("[Got echo connection from ", aSocket host, "]\n")
  while(aSocket isOpen,
   if(aSocket read, aSocket write(aSocket readBuffer asString))
   aSocket readBuffer empty
  )
  write("[Closed ", aSocket host, "]\n")
)

write("[Starting echo server on port 8456]\n")
server := Server clone setPort(8456)
server handleSocket := method(aSocket,
  Echo clone @handleSocketFromServer(aSocket, self)
)
server start
Notes

Io's use of lightweight threading and select for dealing with sockets makes for servers that are much more efficient (both memory and cpu wise) than those written with kernel threads and socket polling.

Starts the server. This method will not return until server is stopped, 
	so you may want to send the start message as an asynchronous message.

slots.handleSocket(aSocket):
This method is called when the server accepts a new socket. The new socket is passed as the argument.
	Override this method in your own server subclass. The default implementation raises an exception.
slots.setPath(path): Sets the path (for Unix Domain sockets) on which the server will listen  for connections. Returns self.

slots.setResponseHeaderString(headerString): Private method that parses the responseHeaders.
slots.referer: Returns the referer String or nil if not set.
slots.fetchRaw: Fetch and return the entire response. Note: This may have problems for some request times.
slots.escapeString(aString): Returns a new String that is aString with the appropriate characters replaced by their URL escape codes.
slots.fetchHttp(optionalProgressBlock): Private method that fetches an http url.
slots.headerBreaks: Private method to connect to the host and write the header.
slots.setURL(urlString): Sets the url string and parses into the protocol, host, port path, and query slots. Returns self.
slots.fetch: Fetches the url and returns the result as a Sequence. Returns an Error, if one occurs.
slots.fetchWithProgress(progressBlock):
Same as fetch, but with each read, progressBlock is called with the readBuffer 
	and the content size as parameters.
slots.openOnDesktop: Opens the URL in the local default browser. Supports OSX, Windows and (perhaps) other Unixes.
slots.post(parameters, headers):
Sends an HTTP post message. If parameters is a Map, its key/value pairs are 
	send as the post parameters. If parameters is a Sequence or String, it is sent directly.
	Any headers in the headers map are sent with the request.
	Returns a sequence containing the response on success or an Error, if one occurs.

slots.setName(aString): Set's the host name. Return self.
slots.name: Returns name.
slots.address:
Returns the IP address. A DNS lookup is done in the background if the 
	address is not already known. Returns an error on lookup failure.

slots.waitOnOrExcept(timeout): Same as waitOn() but an exception is raised if a timeout occurs. Returns self.

slots.setBytesPerRead(numberOfBytes): Sets number of bytes to read per read call. Returns self.
slots.setReadTimeout(seconds): Sets the length of time in seconds for read timeouts on the socket. Returns self.
slots.setSocketReadBufferSize(numberOfBytes): Sets the read buffer size for the socket. Returns self on success or nil on error.
slots.path: Returns the U for the socket.
slots.readTimeout: Returns the length of time in seconds for read timeouts on the socket.
slots.asyncListen: Listens to the socket and returns self immediately or an Error object on error.
slots.asyncStreamWrite(aSeq, start, writeSize):
Writes the slice of aSeq from start to start + writeSize to the socket.
	Returns self immediately if successful, otherwise closes the socket. 
	Returns an error object on Error. 
	Returns nil if the socket is disconnected.
slots.setHost(hostName):
Translates hostName to an IP using asynchronous DNS and sets 
the host attribute. Returns self.
slots.asyncUdpRead(ipAddress, aSeq, readSize):
Reads up to readSize number of bytes from ipAddress into aSeq if data is available. 
	Returns self immediately if successful. Returns an error object on Error. Returns nil if the socket is disconnected.
slots.fromFd(descriptorId, addressFamily): Creates a new Socket with the low-level file descriptor (fd) set to descriptorId and it's address family (AF_INET or AF_UNIX) set to addressFamily.
slots.bytesPerWrite: Returns number of bytes to write per write call.
slots.errorNumber: Returns the socket error number for the last error.
slots.isOpen: Returns true if the socket is open, false otherwise.
slots.streamReadNextChunk(optionalProgressBloc:
Waits for incoming data on the socket and when found, reads any available data and returns self. 
	Returns self on success or an Error object on error or timeout.
slots.setAddress(addressObject): Sets the address (IPAddress or UnixPath) for the socket. Returns self. For IP sockets the setHost() method should generally be used to set the host instead of this method. For Unix Domain sockets use the setPath() method.
slots.host: Returns the host for the socket.
slots.udpReadNextChunk(address):
Waits to receive UDP data from the specified address (IPAddress or UnixPath). 
	As soon as any data is available, it reads all of it into the socket's readBuffer.
	Returns self on success or an Error object on error.
slots.serverWaitForConnection:
Waits for a connection or timeout. When a connection is received, this method returns the connection socket. 
	An Error object is returned on timeour or error.
slots.writeTimeout: Returns the length of time in seconds for write timeouts on the socket.
slots.setNoDelay: Sets the socket to be no-delay. Returns self on success or nil on error.
slots.readMessage:
Empties the readBuffer and reads a 4 byte uint32 in network byte order. 
	This number is the number of bytes in the message payload which are 
	then read into the socket's readBuffer. The readBuffer is returned.
slots.streamRead(numberOfBytes):
Reads numberOfBytes from the socket into the socket's readBuffer. 
	Returns self when all bytes are read or an Error object on error.
slots.errorDescription: Returns a description of the last error on the socket as a string.
slots.getSocketReadLowWaterMark: Returns the read low water mark for the socket on success or nil on error.
slots.getSocketWriteLowWaterMark: Returns the write low water mark for the socket on success or nil on error.
slots.setSocketWriteLowWaterMark(numberOfBytes: Sets the write low water mark for the socket. Returns self on success or nil on error.
slots.descriptorId: Returns the socket's file descriptor id as a Number.
slots.setPath(unixDomainPath): Sets the Unix Domain socket path for the socket. Returns self.
slots.asyncConnect(addressObject): Connects to the given Address and returns self or an Error object on error.
slots.setWriteTimeout(seconds): Sets the length of time in seconds for write timeouts on the socket. Returns self.
slots.setBytesPerWrite(numberOfBytes): Sets number of bytes to write per write call. Returns self.
slots.readListMessage: A shortcut for List fromEncodedList(socket readMessage).
slots.asyncStreamOpen: Submits an async request to open the socket in stream mode and returns self immediately or an Error object on error.
slots.setConnectTimeout(seconds): Sets the length of time in seconds for connect timeouts on the socket. Returns self.
slots.acceptTimeout: Returns the length of time in seconds for accept timeouts on the socket.
slots.setSocketWriteBufferSize(numberOfBytes): Sets the write buffer size for the socket. Returns self on success or nil on error.
slots.writeMessage(aSeq):
Writes a 4 byte uint32 in network byte order containing the size of aSeq. 
	Then writes the bytes in aSeq and returns self.
slots.port: Returns the port number for the socket.
slots.writeFromBuffer(optionalProgressBlock):
Writes the contents of the socket's writeBuffer to the socket. 
	If optionalProgressBlock is supplied, it is periodically called with the number of bytes written as an argument.
	Returns self on success or an Error object on error.
slots.asyncStreamRead(aSeq, readSize):
Reads up to readSize number of bytes into aSeq if data is available. 
	Returns self immediately if successful. Returns an error object on Error. Returns nil if the socket is disconnected.
slots.asyncBind: Binds the socket and returns self immediately or an Error object on error.
slots.isStream: Returns true if the socket is a stream, false otherwise.
slots.streamWrite(buffer, optionalProgressBloc:
Writes buffer to the socket. 
	If optionalProgressBlock is supplied, it is periodically called with the number of bytes written as an argument.
	Returns self on success or an Error object on error.
slots.streamOpen: Opens the socket in stream mode. Returns self.
slots.streamReadWhileOpen:
Reads the stream into the socket's readBuffer until it closes.
	Returns self on success or an Error object on error.
slots.bytesPerRead: Returns number of bytes to read per read call.
slots.udpOpen: Opens the socket in UDP (connectionless) mode. Returns self.
slots.close: Closes the socket and returns self. Returns nil on error.
slots.udpRead(address, numBytes):
Waits for and reads numBytes of udp data from the specified address (IPAddress or UnixPath) into the socket's readBuffer.
	Returns self on success or an Error object on error.
slots.appendToWriteBuffer(aSequence): Appends aSequence to the write buffer if it is non-nil. Returns self.
slots.readUntilSeq(aSequence):
Reads the socket until its readBuffer contains aSequence, then returns a Sequence
	containing the readBuffer's contents up to (but not including) aSequence and clips that section from the readBuffer.
slots.isValid: Returns true if the socket is in valid state, closes the socket and returns false otherwise.
slots.setAcceptTimeout(seconds): Sets the length of time in seconds for accept timeouts on the socket. Returns self.
slots.readBytes(numBytes):
Reads the socket until its readBuffer is numBytes long, then returns a Sequence
	containing the first numBytes of readBuffer's contents and clips that section from the readBuffer.
slots.asyncUdpWrite(ipAddress, aSeq, startInde:
Writes readsize bytes from aSeq starting at startIndex to ipAddress. 
	Returns self immediately if successful. Returns an error object on Error. Returns nil if the socket is disconnected.
slots.setPort(portNumber): Sets the port number for the socket, returns self.
slots.serverOpen:
Opens the socket as a stream, binds it to its address and calls asyncListen to prepare the socket to accept connections.
	Returns self on success or an Error object on error.
slots.connectTimeout: Returns the length of time in seconds for connect timeouts on the socket.
slots.setHost(hostNameOrIpString): Sets the host for the socket. Returns self on success, an Error object otherwise.
slots.address: Returns the address (IPAddress or UnixPath) object for the socket.
slots.asyncUdpOpen: Submits an async request to open the socket in UDP mode and returns self immediately or an Error object on error.
slots.asyncAccept(addressObject): Immediately returns a socket for a connection if one is available or nil otherwise. Returns an Error object on error.
slots.connect: Connects to the socket's host. Returns self on success or an Error object on error.
slots.setSocketReadLowWaterMark(numberOfBytes): Sets the read low water mark for the socket. Returns self on success or nil on error.

Socket.description:
Interface to network communication. Sockets will auto yield to other coroutines while waiting on a request. All blocking operations use the timeout settings of the socket. Reads are appended to the socket's read buffer which can be accessed using the readBuffer method. Example: 
	
socket := Socket clone setHost("www.yahoo.com") setPort(80) connect
if(socket error) then( write(socket error, "\n"); exit)

socket write("GET /\n\n")

while(socket read, Nop)
if(socket error) then(write(socket error, "\n"); exit)

write("read ", socket readBuffer length, " bytes\n")

slots.gaussian(optionalMean, optionalStandardD: Returns a pseudo random number between 0 and 1 with a gaussian distribution.
slots.bytes(count): Returns a Sequence of size count containing random bytes.
slots.value(optionalArg1, optionalArg2):
If called with:
  • no arguments, it returns a floating point random Number between 0 and 1.
  • one argument, it returns a floating point random Number between 0 and optionalArg1.
  • two arguments, it returns a floating point random Number between optionalArg1 and optionalArg2.
slots.setSeed(aNumber): Sets the random number generator seed to the unsigned int version of aNumber.
slots.flip: Returns a random bit as a true or false object.

Random.description: A high quality and reasonably fast random number generator based on Makoto Matsumoto, Takuji Nishimura, and Eric Landry's implementation of the Mersenne Twister algorithm. The default seed is a xor of the ANSI C time() and clock() return values.

BigNum.description: A wrapper for GNU MP Bignum (arbitrary precision math) library. Warning: GMP uses the restrictive GNU license which can be a problem if you are hard linking it into a distributed application.

slots.<<(aNum): Shift left (towards higher bits) op. Returns result.
slots.gcd(aNum): Greatest common denominator op. Returns result.
slots.pow(aNum): Returns power of receiver to aNum.
slots.%(aNum): Modulus op (same as mod()). Returns result.
slots.asNumber: Returns an Io Number for the receiving BigNum.
slots.>>(aNum): Shift right (towards lower bits) op. Returns result.
slots.root(aNum): Returns the aNum root of the receiver.
slots.sqrt: Returns square root of the receiver.
slots.asString: Returns a string representation of the receiver.
slots.hamdist(aNum): Returns hamming distance between receiver and aNum.
slots.lcm(aNum): Least common denominator op. Returns result.
slots.asSimpleString: Returns simple string representation of the receiver.
slots.with(aNumber): Returns a BigNum version of the Io number aNumber.
slots.nextprime: Returns next prime larger than the receiver.

slots.==(other): Compares two numbers against one another. Returns true if they are equal (represent the same number), false otherwise.
slots.serialized: Returns a bit of code which can be used to serialize the Rational number.
slots.gcd(aNum): Calculates the greatest common denominator between the receiver and the argument.
slots.\/(aNum): Returns the value of the receiver divided by aNum.
slots.asString: Returns a text string representing the Rational number.
slots.asRational: Converts the number to a Rational number. CAVEAT: Numbers in Io are floating point entities, which means since they are imprecise, this conversion may yield values not expected.")
slots.compare(other): Compares two numbers against one another. Returns a positive, zero or negative value based on whether the receiver is larger, equal or less than the argument.
slots.-(aNum): Returns the value of the receiver subtracted from aNum.
slots.with(aNumerator, aDenominator): Convenience constructor. Returns a new Rational number whose numerator and denominator are represented by the arguments aNumerator and aDenominator respectively.")
slots.*(aNum): Returns the value of the receiver multiplied by aNum.
slots.+(aNum): Returns the value of the receiver added to aNum.
slots.asNumber: Converts the Rational number to a floating point number.
slots.divmod(aNum): Returns a list containing the integer value and the receiver modulus aNum.
slots.reduce: Reduces the numerator and denominator to their lowest terms.
slots.pow(aNum): Returns the value of the receiver to the power of aNum.
slots.abs: Returns a Rational number with the absolute value of the receiver.
slots.!=(other): Compares two numbers against one another. Returns true if they are equal (represent the same number), false otherwise.

slots.decrypt(aSequence): Returns an decrypted version of aSequence.
slots.beginProcessing: Sets the key from the key slot and initializes the cipher.
slots.endProcessing: Finish processing remaining bytes of inputBuffer.
slots.setIsEncrypting(aBool): If aBool is true, encrypting mode is on, otherwise, decrypting mode is on.
slots.encrypt(aSequence): Returns an encrypted version of aSequence.
slots.process:
Process the inputBuffer and appends the result to the outputBuffer.
	The processed inputBuffer is emptied except for the spare 
	bytes at the end which don't fit into a cipher block.

Blowfish.description:
The Blowfish object can be used to do encryption and decryption using the Blowfish keyed, symmetric block cipher.

Example encryption and decription; 

	
key := "secret"
data := "this is a message"

encryptedData := Blowfish clone setKey(key) encrypt(data)
decryptedData := Blowfish clone setKey(key) decrypt(encryptedData)
Or using the stream API: 
	
key := "secret"
data := "this is a message"

cipher = Blowfish clone
cipher setIsEncrypting(true)
cipher setKey(key)
cipher beginProcessing
cipher inputBuffer appendSeq(data)
cipher process
cipher endProcess
encryptedData := cipher outputBuffer

cipher = Blowfish clone
cipher setIsEncrypting(false)
cipher setKey(key)
cipher beginProcessing
cipher inputBuffer appendSeq(encryptedData)
cipher process
cipher endProcess
decryptedData := cipher outputBuffer

frames
sampleRate
channels
format
seekable
Returns self.
slots.openForWriting:
Opens the file at the path specified in the path slot for writing. The following slots should be set first to specify the output format:

channels
format
Returns self.

Closes the file if it is open. 
	Returns self.

Read a given number of frames (sample pairs).
	Returns self.

Writes aSeq using the format specified by the slots: 
sampleRate
channels
format
Returns the number of frames written.

slots.openForReadingAndWriting: Open audio output and input streams.

TagLib.description:
Used to set meta data tags on the following audio formats: 
ape
flac
mp3
mpc
mpeg
ogg
Supports reading and writing the following attributes: 
title
artist
album
year
track
genre
And reading the attributes: 
bitRate
sampleRate
channels
length
Example use (load and modify a track genre): 
t := TagLib clone setPath("foo.mp3") load
writeln("genre = ", t genre)
t setGenre("ambient")
t save

slots.bos: Indicates if the current page is the beginning of the stream.

Returns the unique serial number of the logical bitstream

OggPacket.description: A wrapper around the libogg ogg_packet object. No methods - used internally.

Provides access to the next packet in the bitstream

slots.packetout(packet): Outputs a packet to the codec-specific decoding engine.
slots.setSerialNumber: Sets the serial number for this stream.

slots.reset: Resets the synchronization status to initial values.

slots.pageout(page): Outputs a page from the synchronisation layer.

slots.slice(start, end, [by]): Returns a list containing the values from the Range starting at the start parameter, ending at the end parameter, and optionally incremented by the by parameter.
slots.index:
Returns the current index number starting from zero and extending 
outward up to the maximum number of items in the range.
slots.asList: Returns a list containing all the items within and including the ranges starting and ending points.
slots.indexOf(aValue): Calculates each value, checking to see if it matches the aValue parameter. If so, return the position within the range. NOTE: This method rewinds the range before searching. If you need to revert back to your original position, make a duplicate of the range, and use indexOf on it instead.
slots.contains: Returns a boolean value if the range contains the argument.
slots.nextInSequence(skipVal): Returns the next item in the sequence.  The optional skipVal parameter allows you to skip ahead skipVal places.
slots.levenshtein(other): Returns the levenshtein distance to other.
slots.setRange(start, end, increment):
Has several modes of operation. First, if only two parameters are specified, 
	the increment value is set to 1 by default, while the first parameter represents
	the point to start from, and the second parameter represents the point to end at. 
	If the second parameter is smaller than the first, the range will operate backwards. 
	If the third parameter is specified, a custom iteration value will be used instead of 1.
slots.previous:
Sets the current item in the range to the previous item in the range, 
	and returns a boolean value indicating whether it is not at the beginning of the range.
slots.toBy(endingPoint, incrementValue): Convenience constructor that returns a cursor object representing the range of numbers from the receiver to the 'endingPoint' parameter. Increments over each item in that range by the 'incrementValue' parameter.
slots.foreach(optionalIndex, value, message):
Iterates over each item beginning with the starting point, and finishing at the ending point inclusive. This method can operate several ways; these include: (1) Takes one argument, the message tree to be executed during each iteration; (2) Takes two arguments, the first argument is the name of the current value being iterated over, and the second is the message tree to be executed during each iteration; (3) Takes three arguments: the first is the current index within the range, the second is the name of the current value being iterated over, and the third is the message tree to be executed during each iteration. For example: 
// First method (operating on numbers)
1 to(10) foreach("iterating" print) // prints "iterating" 10 times
// Second method (operating on numbers)
1 to(10) foreach(v, v print) // prints each value
// Third method (operating on numbers)
1 to(10) foreach(i, v, writeln(i .. ": " .. v)) // prints "index: value"
slots.next:
Sets the current item in the range to the next item in the range, 
		and returns a boolean value indicating whether it is not at the end of the range.
slots.rewind: Sets the current item and the index to the values the receiver started out with.
slots.to: Convenience constructor that returns a cursor object representing the range of numbers from the receiver to the 'endingPoint' parameter. Increments over each item in that range by 1.
slots.value: Returns the value of the current item in the range.
slots.map(optionalIndex, value, message):
Returns a new list which contains the result of the 'body' for every element stepped over in the range, from the starting point to the ending point inclusive. This method can operate several ways; these include: (1) Takes one argument, the message tree to be executed during each iteration; (2) Takes two arguments, the first argument is the name of the current value being iterated over, and the second is the message tree to be executed during each iteration; (3) Takes three arguments: the first is the current index within the range, the second is the name of the current value being iterated over, and the third is the message tree to be executed during each iteration. For example: 
# First method (operating on numbers)
1 to(10) map(*2) # multiply each value by two
# Second method (operating on numbers)
1 to(10) map(v, "#{v}" interpolate) # returns string representation of each value as list
# Third method (operating on numbers)
1 to(10) map(i, v, i*v) #  multiply each value by index
slots.at(position): Rewinds the range, skips forward until we're at the supplied position then returns the value at that position. Raises an exception if the position is out of bounds.
slots.last: Moves the current cursor to the end of the range, and returns it.
slots.to(endpoint): Convenience constructor that returns a range of sequences from the receiver to the endpoint argument. Increments over each item in that range by 1.
slots.first: Moves the current cursor to the beginning of the range, and returns it.
slots.toBy(endpoint, increment): Convenience constructor that returns a range of sequences from the receiver to the endpoint argument. Increments over each item in that range by the value of the increment parameter. The increment parameter must be positive.

Range.description: Simple datastructure representing the items at and between two specific points.

slots.setSender(anObject): Sets the sender of the Notification. Returns self.

slots.setAction(messageName): Sets the name of the message that is sent to the target when a matching notification is found. Returns self.

slots.sender: Returns the sender that the listener wants to receive messages from.
slots.action: Returns the name of the message that is sent to the target when a matching notification is found.
slots.setTarget(anObject): Sets the target that the receiver sends matching messages to. Returns self.
slots.setName(aSeq): Sets the message name that the listener wants to receive messages for. Returns self.

slots.setLink(aValue): Sets the link pointer. Returns self.
slots.link: Returns the link pointer or Nil if none is set.

WeakLink.description:
A WeakLink is a primitive that can hold a reference to 
	an object without preventing the garbage collector from 
	collecting it. The link reference is set with the setLink() method. 
	After the garbage collector collects an object, it informs any 
	(uncollected) WeakLink objects whose link value pointed to that 
	object by calling their "collectedLink" method.

slots.callPluginInit(functionName):
Call's the dll function of the specified name. 
	Returns the result as a Number or raises an exception on error.
slots.isOpen: Returns true if the library is open, or false otherwise.
slots.setPath(aString): Sets the path to the dynamic library. Returns self.
slots.open: Opens the dynamic library and returns self or raises a DynLoad.open Error if there is an error.
slots.call(functionName, <arg1>, <arg2>, ...):
Call's the dll function of the specified name with the arguments provided. 
	Returns the a Number with the result value.
slots.setInitFuncName(aString): Sets the initialization function name for the dynamic library. Returns self.

slots.pack(format, value1, ...):
Returns a new Sequence with the values packed in.

	Codes:
	
	*: (one at the beginning of the format string) declare format string as BigEndian
	B: unsigned byte
	b: byte
	C: unsigned char
	c: char
	H: unsigned short
	h: short
	I: unsigned int
	i: int
	L: unsigned long
	l: long
	f: float
	F: double
	s: string

	A '*' at the begging of the format string indicates native types are to be treated as Big Endiand.
	
	A number preceding a code declares an array of that type.
	
	In the case of 's', the preceding number indicates the size of the string to be packed.
	If the string passed is shorter than size, 0 padding will be used to fill to size. If the
	string passed is longer than size, only size chars will be packed.
	
	The difference between b/B and c/C is in the values passed to pack. For b/B pack expects a number.
	For c/C pack expects a one-char-string (this is the same as '1s' or 's')
	
	Examples:
	
	s := Sequence pack("IC5s", 100, "a", "hello")
	s := Sequence pack("5c", "h", "e", "l", "l", "o")
	s := Sequence pack("I", 0x01020304)
	s := Sequence pack("*I", 0x01020304)

Sequence.description:
A Sequence is a container for a list of data elements. Typically these elements are each 1 byte in size. A Sequence can be either mutable or immutable. When immutable, only the read-only methods can be used.

Terminology

  • Buffer: A mutable Sequence of single byte elements, typically in a binary encoding
  • Symbol or String: A unique immutable Sequence, typically in a character encoding
